column1: Parathyroidectomy is surgery to remove the parathyroid glands or parathyroid tumors.
You will receive general anesthesia (asleep and pain-free) for this surgery.
Usually the parathyroid glands are removed using a 2- to 4-inch surgical cut on your neck.
If you have this shot, your surgeon will use a special probe, like a Geiger counter, to locate the parathyroid gland.
- Video-assisted parathyroidectomy: Your surgeon will make two small cuts in your neck.
Your surgeon will use the camera to view the area and will remove the diseased glands with the instruments.
Your doctor may recommend this surgery if one or more of your parathyroid glands is producing too much parathyroid hormone.
It is often caused by a small non-cancerous (benign) tumor called an adenoma.

Risks for anesthesia and surgery in general are: - Reactions to medicines or breathing problems - Bleeding, blood clots, or infection Risks for parathyroidectomy are: - Injury to the thyroid gland or the need to remove part of the thyroid gland - Hypoparathyroidism.
The anesthesiologist is the doctor who will give you the medicine that makes you asleep and pain-free during surgery and who monitors you during surgery.
These include aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), clopidogrel (Plavix), warfarin (Coumadin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), and other drugs like these.
Call your surgeon if you have any numbness or tingling around your mouth in the 24 to 48 hours after surgery.
Your surgeon may want to see you and might suggest you can take calcium supplements until the symptoms go away.
